column1: Kalemie
column3: is a town on the western shore of Lake Tanganyika in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The town is next to the outflow of the Lukuga River from Lake Tanganyika to the Lualaba River.

column1: == History ==
From 1886 to 1891
column2: the Society of Missionaries of Africa had founded catholic missions at the north and south ends of Lake Tanganyika. Léopold Louis Joubert
column3: a French soldier and armed auxiliary
column4: was dispatched by Archbishop Charles Lavigerie's Society of Missionaries of Africa to protect the missionaries. The missionaries abandoned three of the new stations due to attacks by Tippu Tip and Rumaliza. By 1891 the Arab slave traders had control of the entire western shore of the lake
column5: apart from the region defended by Joubert around Mpala and St Louis de Mrumbi. The anti-slavery expedition under Captain Alphonse Jacques—financed by the Belgian Anti-Slavery Society—came to the relief of Joubert on 30 October 1891. When the Jacques expedition arrived Joubert's garrison was down to about two hundred men
column6: poorly armed with "a most miscellaneous assortment of chassepots
column8: without suitable cartridges." He also had hardly any medicine left. Captain Jacques asked Joubert to remain on the defensive while his expedition moved north.

column1: === Founding of Albertville ===
On 30 December 1891 Captain Alphonse Jacques' anti-slavery expedition founded the military post of Albertville on the shores of Lake Tanganyika
column2: and tried to put an end to the Arab slave trade in the region.

column1: Albertville was located 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) south of the Lukuga River. Sergeant Alexis Vrithoff was killed on 5 April 1892 when defending Albertville against an attack by Arab slavers under Rumaliza.  His troops
column3: surrounded Albertville on that day and besieged the outpost for several months
column4: from 16 August 1892 until 1 January 1893. Eventually Rumaliza's forces had to retreat because of the arrival of the Long-Duvivier-Demol Anti-Slavery expedition
column5: a relief column sent from Brussels at captain Alphonse Jacques's aide.

column1: After the Arabs left the territory
column2: the original Albertville was gradually abandoned
column3: and the name became attached to the military post of M'Toa to the north of the Lukuga

column1: === World War I and the East African campaign ===
In 1914 Albertville was the base for the Belgo-Congolese forces in the East African campaign. The railway reached Albertville in 1915
column2: and in 1916 the port was constructed and the coalworks at Greinerville opened. At the end of 1940 a military base was established at Albertville
column3: initially South African and later British
column4: to manage troops in Kenya and Abyssinia.

column1: === Post-independence and name change to Kalemie ===

Albertville was attacked by mercenaries under Major Mike Hoare during operations against the Simba Rebellion in August 1964.In the late 1960s and early 1970s under the regime of Mobutu Sese Seko the Zairianization policy was implemented
column2: this included numerous changes to the state and to private life
column3: including the renaming of the Congo and its cities
column4: as well as an eventual mandate that Zairians were to abandon their Christian names for more "authentic" ones. In addition
column5: Western style attire was banned and replaced with the Mao-style tunic labeled the "abacost" and its female equivalent. The policy began to wane in the late 1970s and had mostly been abandoned by 1990.

column2: as a result of the Zairianization
column3: Albertville changed its name to Kalemie. The Town of Kalemie also hosts the major University of Kalemie
column4: which maintains the largest library in the region.

column1: == Kalemie Port ==
The port at Kalemie was built to connect the Great Lakes rail line (from the Kabalo junction on the Lualaba River) to the Tanzanian lake port and railhead at Kigoma
column2: from where the Tanzanian Central Railway Line runs to the seaport of Dar es Salaam. The port was built with a 130 m wharf and 3 mobile cranes
column3: giving it a capacity of 500 tonnes per day with two shifts. Currently
column5: and vessels cannot reach the wharf due to silting up of the lake next to it. The buildings of the port also require rehabilitation. Moreover
column6: the railway line for 100 km west of Kalemie is 'very degraded' and not fully operational.

column1: Kalemie Port is also used by boat services to the northern Lake Tanganyika ports of Kalundu-Uvira and Bujumbura in Burundi
column2: and southwards to Moba and Mpulungu in Zambia.

column1: Kalemie Port is operated by the railway company SNCC which also operates the railways in DR Congo (except for the Matadi-Kinshasa line) as well as boat services on the eastern waterways in the country.

== 2005 earthquake ==
The Lake Tanganyika earthquake struck on December 5
column2: 2005. The epicentre was approximately 10 km (6.2 mi) below the surface of Lake Tanganyika
column3: some 55 km south-east of Kalemie. At least dozens of houses were destroyed.
